Description: Mould-made scaraboid in glazed composition; back modelled in the shape of a Black African head with short broad nose and thick lips; underside decorated with incised representation of winged lion (or griffin?) with vertical dash in front; laterally pierced above ears for suspension; light greenish beige glaze; core yellow in colour.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This scaraboid is on display in the Museum of Fine Arts and was photographed through glass. The label reports that the device represents a 'lion with crescent moon above'. It can be identified as Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, 60. Winged mythological creatures are commonly depicted on scarabs and scaraboids at Naukratis (on this production, see Webb forthcoming). This piece belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-103, 106-107, Type XXVIII A, subtype A116-117, but see A115 for this piece wrongly identified as a Bes head scaraboid). For rather similar African head scaraboids from Naukratis see for example: Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no.100 (BM 1886,0401.1666.A) and 145 (BM 1886,0401.1693); Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 55 (BM 1888,0601.5681) and 61 (Boston, Museum of Fine Artson 88.872). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund). Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 97, Type XXVIII A115) (but not a Bes head)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.068) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5780 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
